job_title: Work At Home Pharmacist in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros:
You work from home 
Some flexibility
Some room for growth and different tasks 
Good if you can work independently with little or no guidance
cons:
-they take advantage of fact you work at home and expect you to spend all day waiting for work to appear in production queues
-they expect you to check over 1000 rxs per day
- no work life balance despite company rhetoric to the contrary 
- very little guidance when issues arise
- salary was below average with no pay increase for 5+ years
- layoffs, layoffs, layoffs with very little recognition  or regard to many years of service by a group

review_title: I feel very valued by my immediate supervisor, but not by the company.
pros: The benefits are better than I've experienced anywhere in the last several years.  It is a successful company that cares about their patients.
cons: It is nearly impossible to get time off unless you request it a month or more in advance. We don't always know that we need a day that far in advance. It is a bit strict and there is no flexibility.

review_title: Discredits anonymous reviews proceeds to conduct "anonymous" review with unique tracking number tied to each employee.
pros: Its a paycheck. Can't really say much more then it beats nit working. Will have to deal with it until next jib somewhere else.
cons: Upper management does not care about employees.  No work/life balance. Not looking to retain hi value assets. Review process is a popularity contest, forget hard work getting you anywhere. Its a house of cards, its a mystery how its still in business.

job_title: Senior Operations Manager Consumer Directed Healthcare
pros: Benefits , Peers, Opportunity, company outlook,
cons: Some harsh changes that impact jobs for some areas are major and not something that seems to be forewarned , review process for end of year needs many changes. Also it would be nice to include W@H peers in celebrations, and other campus activities.  Many had no choice to work from home as the merger caused some locations to shut down, also for those that did not choose to work from home i think the company should reimburse for internet utilized for company work.

pros: In-depth training, very generous vacation benefits and insurance coverage.
cons:
Shifts available - I was given 2 non-consecutive days off.  Pay was just a little over minimum wage and really horrible for the work required.  A benefit to me was thinking that it could lead to opportunities within the company, but in training we learned that even to apply for another call center position in another location - the only option was to quit, move to the other location and then apply.  

The final straw was learning that bathroom breaks were only to be done during scheduled breaks or the 1 % of personal time given each day, even if you were sick and really needed to use the bathroom.

review_title: Not the worst... but not the best... they have a long way to climb
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Edina, MN
pros: Senior leadership is under a transition period.  They seem to be concerned about the lack of employee engagement and are trying to change the culture.
cons: The mid level leadership is lacking training.  Therefore some leaders are strong and provide great direction/motivation and opportunities.  Others are the complete opposite and are just focused on climbing the ladder.  If you are lucky to work for one that is strong, that is great!  But there is considerable turn over so the likelihood that they will be there long is not high.

pros: Express Scripts has a very effective software F14 that it inherited from Medco which aids pharmacists and technicians with accurate data entry, potential drug/drug, drug/allergies, drug/disease interactions, as well as streamline processing for highly accuracy and efficiency:  Green, Yellow, or Red indicators.  Express Scripts is all about numbers AND accuracy. I liked my job and enjoyed working for Express Scripts while I was there.  The company culture was friendly, everybody was very supportive of one another.
cons: Shrinking business and potential mass layoff.

pros:
Average Benefits Package - nothing special at all
Nice Co-Workers - one of the few good things about this place
Work Location is Convenient
cons:
Wow - where to start - this company used to be a fairly decent place to work - but over the last two years they have shifted to a very heavy emphasis on contract labor - over twenty five percent of their work force is now contractors.  

The Bloomington location is a complete mess - so many IT employees have been laid off over the last year that many knowledgeable people are gone and they are replaced by contractors - not employees.  With annual March bonuses paid out - more and more people are leaving voluntarily - they are so fed up with the work environment - laid off workers are not replaced so those left have to take on extra work.  The bloomington location is slowly being down-sized through lay-offs and through people who are just sick and tired of management and how they are treating this location - management has to be in a panic given the number of people that are leaving that location.  I'm sure they though they could control the downsizing and the job market would keep people there until they were ready to dismiss people - but that's not what is happening - people are leaving faster than they can deal with it.  The Bloomington location has not hired new employees in a long time - people leave and are not replaced.

The performance review process is a complete joke - forced ranking process so there is always a percentage of people who get low ratings - it just has to be that way - only so many people can get rated highly - so what you actually do over the course of a year really doesn't matter - it doesn't mean you will be recognized for it.

The company does not recognize people - they rarely do any company recognition events as they are too cheap!!!   For a company that made a billion in profit last year they could do a much better job - this is not a good place to work any longer so you would be better served looking elsewhere.

job_title: Data Entry Pharmacy Technician in Harrisburg, PA
pros: Listening to music while doing work.
cons:
In a large, building-wide meeting we were told that everyone giving terrible reviews on Glassdoor was just an disgruntled former employee, and nothing more. Well, yes, I am a former employee and I am disgruntled... but I quit, I did not get fired...
Very insufficient training, as every trainer was different and therefore every new class of trainees got different rules and regulations.
I have never complained about the pay at any job before, but for the knowledge required and the responsibility you have, the pay is way way too low.
There is zero sense of any type of community.
An employee such as myself, whose lowest accuracy was 96% but usually stuck around 98-99%, gets absolutely no bonus pay or incentives. I was treated the exact same as the employees whose accuracy was well below 90%. I had to beg for 9 months to even be allowed to assist those with low accuracy. Management does not care about employees improving themselves.
Management was all very immature. Mood swings, cliques, and a response of "He's just young" to a harassment claim against a Team Lead. Lunches were hours-long. Employees were told to be dead silent but yet management walked around yelling hellos at each other and talking very loudly about personal issues. 
Very shady practices going on also in regards to things that impact employees. We were told there might be a schedule and pay change that many people did not agree with. The management pulled people into rooms individually and asked invasive questions: Are you married? Yes. How many cars do you have? When I told them one car, they asked where my spouse works and how my spouse gets to work. I told them my spouse's occupation and how he carries out his day is none of their business.  How many children do you have and who cares for them? I also told them this was absolutely none of their business.
Management was never interested in assisting anyone in advancing. I had found a position I was interested in and emailed my resume and intentions to the appropriate person and no one ever contacted me. The recruiter and my supervisor would not assist me, and I could not get the person hiring for the job to even pay me the time of day.
I noticed some very dangerous, patient-impacting things taking place but no one cared. I kept a spreadsheet of 3 employees, hundreds of times, shipping medication to the incorrect person and/or address. These employees were not fired, given additional training, nor were they even spoken to about their mistakes.
Attendance became the most important thing in the world to them, after not mattering at all for the longest time. I came to work on a very major highway that had accidents quite a bit. Every time I was late I called from the traffic, and let them know. It's not like I could have lied, because I could prove, through news stories, all of the accidents that I was stuck behind. They never hit me with attendance points... until I told them I was considering quitting. Then, in about 15 minutes, my supervisor came to me and told me I was half a point away from being fired for points that I had accumulated but was never approached about, and happened before the new attendance policy came about. I quit the next week.

pros: The Company is an industry leader, the compensation is ok, the values are to be admired.
cons: The culture dictates eminent burn out.  The compensation has decreased for legacy Medco Employees and the incentive for excellence and growth have diminished.

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Saint Marys, GA
pros: Express Scripts was one of my favorite employers. Working as part of a team, yet independently, you are able to choose your own schedule.  As long as you have good attendance, adhere to your schedule, don't get involved in the drama of others,  this is a wonderful place to work. Employees are treated fairly. You have the ability to earn extra money based on your performance.  The atmosphere is energetic and friendly.
cons: You have to be able to tune out the noise of co-workers. That's it. There was nothing I did not like about working at Express Scripts.

pros: this is the WORST company company one  could ever work for.  RUN !!!  they have NO concern for devoted employees and certainly  NO CONCERN FOR PATIENTS THEY ARE SUPOSSED TO SERVE. THEY TREAT NURSES LIKE DIRT !!
cons: stock will drop soon as no one could make money the way they treat employees   benefits are terrible and people are treated so bad    I would be starving before I would ever work for these maniacs again

review_title: If not corporate then you are nothing
pros: The company is big and employs a lot of people. It sure seems to take care of those that work at corporate with a great environment but then any of the other locations are not considered at all. CEO will engage corporate offices but does not care about the rest.
cons: Literally are treated horrible. You get to see all of these corporate employees provide work life balance and local employees are not given any of those same perks. They open and close sites with impunity turn employees lives upside down all in an effort to fool the stock holders into thinking everything is going well. Eventually it will catch up with them.

pros: LOTS of locations across the country; call centers, pharmacies, corp headquarters in St. Louis; work from home opportunities
cons: After the acquisition of Medco Health things started to diminish--most former Medco people were laid off after they trained their replacements.  Wages were MUCH lower, the bottom line seemed more important than patient care, and almost no one could work fast enough to satisfy the "goals"--this included the supervisors also.  Very sad day that the company at the top of the heap forgot who built it into what it was at its glory--the employees who never forgot that they REALLY worked for the patient.

review_title: Express Scripts and UBC will treat you like a number.
job_title: Clinical Specialist in Kansas City, MO
pros: The Pros are the people who I work with. They are the only reason I can last 8 hours a day.
cons: The culture at KC UBC is toxic. Employees got in trouble for complaining from upper management when we requested more training. UBC prefers people who work to meet the minimum and fly under the radar.  They prefer to be reactive rather than proactive because being proactive involves too much effort. Negative reactions when you try to go above and beyond.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: They allow work at home for the technology department most of the time.
cons: Morale is terrible, they do horrible job letting employees know they care. We are constantly under staffed, and it seems like the solution is additional micro-managing. Rather then hiring a decent technical personal, at a reasonable salary, they bring in inexperienced junior people, which isn't inherently bad, people have to start somewhere, but they refuse to give people quality training and coaching to get them to be senior level people.

pros: After a long string of bad press about employee satisfaction a couple of years ago they have been on a mission to improve.  Management is now rated on employee engagement & satisfaction, and the signs of improvement are beginning to show.  I am not sure I would recommend to a friend yet but compared to a year or two ago they are much better.
cons: Work life balance is still not great but improving.

pros: I like working here.  I've been here over 5 years and enjoy the challenge.  A place like this is what you make it.  I know it gets a bad wrap but I see it as a challenge to change it.  There are many really talented people here trying to make a difference.  The goal is to find those people and then help them be successful!  In turn, making yourself successful.    I'm here for at least 5 more!
cons: Change.  If you don't like change, don't come.  The world is full of change and business is no different.

review_title: A good place to break into the healthcare industry
job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Tampa, FL
pros: work at home, layoffs are rare,  great benefits, monthly bonus, periodic contests to win prizes or redemption points, good management, friendly employees, paid vacation, paid time off, low turnover
cons: schedule, high seniority, benefits don't kick in for 90 days, 4 weeks training, periodic changing of rules, some issues with phone system, outdated software

review_title: Cheapest company that screws thier employees.
job_title: Prescription Benefit Specialist in Columbus, OH
pros: Insurance plan is decent, weekly pay, stable job, clean office, a lot of paid time off (~20 days a year) and free coffee.
cons: They bought out my company and cut my pay by ~$13,000 a year.  I could manage if they only allowed overtime, but they took that away too. They are cheap, and they have no concern for thier employees.  Can't move up the chain b/c no jobs open, only close now, and I am a minority there (white male).  Our dept. make an avg of $14.50 an hour plus bonus, they made it so we all have to quit b/c they only want to pay $10.00 an hour for it.

review_title: This is the Walmart of PBMs.
job_title: Client Benefit Analyst in Bloomington, MN
pros: Good co-workers that are motivated with advancement opportunity..
cons: Company lacks direction and is in way over it's head for this merger with MedCo. Express Way or the Highway mentality isn't going to work.. Was waiting for all our jobs to go overseas and then have them hire back the Americans for less money...

review_title: There is no way I want to keep working here. Everyone is unhappy
pros: The only benefit is the 401k. Automated system to call out so you are not put on a guilt trip for family emergencies
cons: there are so many cons I don't know where to start. Higher management is a joke. They gossip non stop. They won't help you off they don't think it meets business needs. They tell you to have other people take care of your kids if they are sick/in the hospital. If not they threaten to fire you. Upper management picks on specific pcas and talks down to them and yells at them in the front of others. They make you feel embarrassed if you have issues outside of work.

review_title: ESI is fast paced place to work, if only the culture and work/life balance could improve.
pros: Get to work with a broad array of companies.  Work is not really dull.  Certainly get to deal with new challenges on a daily basis.
cons: Zero work life balance.  Culture is hurt as a result.  I had one manager almost miss the birth of their child.  Direct management is not supportive of movement to other departments.  If you are a solid performer, they try to keep you in the department.  Very little transparency from upper management.

pros: The pay was excellent, and they have a good 401K matching program.  Facility is new and nice.  My input about making things better for our department was acknowledged and appreciated at the director/senior manager level. Extracurricular opportunities to contribute to the organization were a great plus.  Pharmacists all helpful and knowledgeable.
cons:
Forced ranking is  unprofessional and allows supervisors to play favorites and not reward deserving employees.   Supervisors themselves are not very professional and don't know what's going on.  Communication across remote offices is not very good, and supervisors focus on "complainers" rather than creating an environment where people can get work done. Little discipline for talkers and troublemakers, and complaints because you can't do your job equals a writeup.  Punishing people for legit complaints  to maintain a "good atmosphere" is just bad management and dysfunctional.
Also, Whitestown is in the middle of nowhere!  Work-at-home is a necessity for a lot of people, except only the office talkers get the privilege so that supervisors can hide and forget the behavioral problems in their department.
Sodexo food in cafeteria is overpriced and tastes awful!  Sodexo also made the company get rid of vending machines with affordable options.  Healthy options are nonexistent, and variety is a joke.  
Senior management sends employees surveys to promote engagement and employee satisfaction, yet vertical communication up through the organization is squashed by the aforementioned supervisors and middle managers silencing their staff.
Health insurance is substandard for an organization of this size and revenue, because the formulary is limited and pays only for older cheaper drugs.  Also, out-of-pocket costs are high, although this is due Obamacare.
Hiring new people then downsizing them less than a year later showed that there were too many cooks in the kitchen with different plans.

job_title: Sales and Account Management in Bridgeton, MO
pros: Some good benefits, and many have the opportunity to work from home. Large size allows ESI to be price competitive, which allows for some security.
cons: Newer management is not focused on customer or client needs, and is very short term oriented. They lack experience, and disregard advice from experienced, industry experts.

review_title: Definitely Takes A Strong Person To Work Here
job_title: Resolution Team Lead in Saint Marys, GA
pros:
If you pay attention, learn from your trainer, seek new opportunities, and understand their processes then you'll do great. Expect change, its the nature of the market this company is in. 

I have to say, I ended my career as what is known as an RTL. I can honestly say, I'm one of the few who knew the processes, understood the business, and my fellow coworkers came to me for advice on calls all the time. Thats why o took the promotion. If you like being the one who patients go to when they ask for a supervisor because you have a way with people or you seem to know a lot and everyone ask you questions all the time, why not get more money doing what you do best and take a position on the RTL team?
cons:
Work and home life balance is not great, HR issues are hard to resolve as there is no one physically there you can go to. They have outsourced their HR to a 3rd party.

Be prepared to get yelled at ALL the time. This job is by no means for the weak. You can't just yell back at the customer either. Working for this company can really put you on edge, test your patience, and challenge your ability to tell the customer to stop being a self centered entitled bleep because you are simply the messenger and yes, you are under fire a lot!

Your job will be ever changing. From what clients you lean to the processes themselves, your job will never be as easy as it was during your training. This is not a bad thing if you excell at things like this, but if you don't like change, this is the wrong job for you.

job_title: Eligibility Associate in Lake Mary, FL
pros: Decent pay, good benefits, satisfaction in the work itself and with the concept of feeling like youre making a difference in patients/customers lives.
cons: Terrible management at the time. Bonuses were given to supervisors 2 close friends, instead of based productivity. No one else on a team of about 20 received bonuses when we had great workers on the team. They placed people in leading roles that were new to the team and didn't know how it functioned or details on the program, rather than a seasoned team member. They did not care about their employees and continued to push numbers and even when we met those goals, they would still be unsatisfied because their were new goals they expected you to hit, even if you were above the target range. This caused high stress levels for the employees and not enough positive feedback. Headquarters HR realized my team was the only team in the building incorrectly getting paid. We were suppose to start at $19 an hour and were told we would receive back pay that never happened. Our job title was not suppose to involve insurance investigations or verification or appeals and pretty much only dealt with inbound calls therefore we were doing work outside of our job title and getting paid for the lesser job position while doing double the work. Whenever I went to a supervisor for assistance, with the new management system, I was told to "google it" or to ask someone else when the process was to go to a supervisor, not to mention they were my last resort and these company policy questions cant be found on google.

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Saint Marys, GA
pros:
They have a plan that offers very cheap prescriptions. 
If you can afford the deductibles.
cons:
Can't hear calls
Very unprofessional until the point that it is embarrassing when your on calls. Encouraged to be rude to Medicare recepiants to cut calls short. Elders will call crying because they have to choose between food or meds. There are ways to help them but you will get introuble if you tell them about this because Company will loose money!

review_title: Impersonal Company Concerned about one thing only....the bottom line
pros:
Powerful tools to help manage clients and provide comprehensive metrics and analyses
Detailed guidelines for how you will be performed
Fair compensation and benefits package
cons:
While the company preaches integrity, compassion, etc. it is simply not the case. One of the most toxic working cultures I have been involved in. Little colloboration between teammates and management definitely played favorites. 

I was "acquired" in a buyout by Express Scripts in 2009. The company I came from was told only 10-20% of transitioned employees would be laid off in the first two months. It turned out, nearly 80% were laid off in the first month in a half. However, the company was still able to host an annual sales conference for 700 emplyees in February, while 700 employees lost their jobs the next month.

The culture was not inviting for those of us left. We were referred to as the former company's employees by staff and we knew our time was limited. In November, we were told that our jobs were safe by a Senior Level VP and that there was more work than they knew what to do with. Once the transaction happened, most of our clients were released or we were forced to manage them so poorly that they would leave if the contract could not be voided. For those who lost clients, they were laid off unceremoniously, even though several similar positions were still being opened.

In a nutshell, I was forced to leave a company I was very happy with and experienced first hand the losing end of a corporate takeover. While the company does invest heavily in their sales organization, you are simply a number to them. As profitable as the company is and as metric focused as they are, they do not compensate their Account Directors appropriately for basically being sales people. There is only an annual bonus that is decided on department metrics, rather than a commission scale based on individual performance.

I am happy to be away from such a toxic environment and would not recommend this company to those who value integrity and compassion.

review_title: The purpose of health care is to provide health to patients too.
pros: They are very large. Slightly better IT than accredo/medco. They aggressively encourage a smoke free environment. Provide company rental cars for traveling employees.
cons:
changing policies and practices that have proven themselves to be patient advantageous and profitable.
removal of Accredo personal that had enormous skill and replaced with express scripts people who had no or limited experience.

pros:
- They are closed on all major holidays and you are compensated for them.
- There is a lot of vacation/paid time offered to employees (around 20 or so days a year).
- Great benefits.
- Mostly friendly coworkers.
- The cafeteria has good food, albiet a little pricy.
- Website for employees has a lot of great features and is easy to navigate.
- On-site credit union is a great idea.
- The facility is state-of-the-art and very well-maintained.
- The goals set by the company for employees tend to be very attainable.
cons:
- Constant changes made to Standard Operating Procedures make it impossible to keep up with ever-shifting rules, resulting in "counseling" from a superior (verbal warning, etc.)
- Employees are told multiple times a week that "mandatory overtime" is required on Saturday (the normal days are Monday-Friday) and then told it isn't required the next day and vice versa. This makes it very hard to keep a good balance of home life.
- Since being named the 2nd worst company to work for by the Wall Street Journal, the entire company has been scrambling to fix their relationship with their employees. This means asking on what they improve, online surveys, etc. That makes sense. However, as far as day-to-day things, there have been no changes. In the article, people had complained about being overworked, and the week the employees were asked for suggestions on improving the company, they were made to work that Saturday.
- Anytime these Mandatory days are ordered, if an employee voices any concern, they're to to put "the patient first". This essentially is telling them to put the patient's needs above their own and their family's need.
- They turn employees against each other (inadvertently) by having them report what was not done in their section by the other shift. Then that shift is told what mistakes they made. Since you know exactly who is working in your section/area on the other shift, this makes for some incredibly awkward situations between employees and months/years of this can cause some real friction.
- Some members of management seem to hold grudges towards cetain employees and managers. This tension also creates awkward situations.
- Employees/managers tend to lash out at one another when overworked (though some of this is voluntary overtime that the employee decided to work, as opposed to the company forcing them to). Some employees will work an extra 2-4 hours a day and, as a result, become irritable and leave other employees stressed out, and in turn angry, from dealing with tired coworkers.

review_title: A place you can't  wait to leave!
pros: Working at Medco was a pleasure.  Medco had the client and customers best interest at heart and treated their employees well.  THEN we were purchased by express
cons: Express scripts leadership seemed to be  all about making money.  Clients are not treated well and employees are treated worse,  It's all smoke and mirrors...may look like a good place to work, but don't believe what they tell you.  HR is the worst, upper management hasn't a clue of what is really going on and worse yet, they don't care.  Just keep bringing the money in!

job_title: Reimbursement Specialist in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Medical benefits and 401K only. Good location and most of the older employees that were hired under Healthbridge are good people
cons: Overwork your employees. Don't want to pay employees what they are worth. No advancement unless you know someone.  If you care about your employees you're pushed out the door.

review_title: ESI purchased Medco in 2012 the two cultures have not clicked well. Lack of respect by the STL corporate office.
job_title: IT Director in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Need for a job, not a carrier place.
cons: Lack of respect, does not pay well if you are located on the east. It is a sweat shop to work in and Senior management  does not care about it people. Medco culture was to make medicine better to it's clients the ESI culture to make money at any costs. The yearly review process called calibration is a complete farce and totally subjective.

job_title: Senior Director in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: Large company with the ability to advance. It's critical to have client facing experience to maximize your promotion opportunities. ESI has built a larger and stronger organization through continued acquisition.
cons: The account management organization has struggled to assemble itself and retain good employees since the Medco acquisition. The teams are too lean and struggle to adequately support client needs. Very little work/life balance. Account management leadership turnover has created a fragmented and inconsistent business model.

pros: If you like a fast-paced environment where you're changing millions of lives for the better every day, and you get a chance to work with great people who are as passionate about healthcare as you are, Express Scripts is the right place to be.
cons: You're going to work hard, but it's well worth it. Rewarding opportunities and you get more of them, the more you collaborate with your colleagues across the organization.

job_title: Data Entry Technician in Trevose, PA
pros: independent work by yourself on a computer all day (which could actually be good or bad depending on the person), mostly stress free, good for benefits such as health insurance and paid time off.
cons: the pay is very low. the treatment of employees who have been there for 15+ years is very disheartening. They fired someone who wasn't hitting their numbers who had worked there for quite a while. (this person had health conditions!!!)

pros: The company seems genuinely invested in its resources with solid benefits and compensation. My managers have all been available and insightful. Direction, while not initially clear, is always a phone call or IM away.
cons: Strategies seem to shift on a daily basis and from leader to leader. It would be one problem if it were constantly shifting to the "hot new thing" but it vacillates between existing strategies without proper investment to realize benefits.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great Benefits, Health Insurance, Tuition Reimbursement, 401K with Employer Matching Contributions, Employee Stock Purchase Plan. Wonderful people to work with. Strong company to work for. Pay could be worse.
cons: Large number of lay offs due to merger. Pay could be better. Lack of communication between departments. Uncertain of future business plans. Value of employees takes a back seat to making the numbers. Limited opportunities to advance. Company more likely to hire from outside than to promote from within.

job_title: Prescription Benefit Specialist in Mason, OH
pros: Great management and people to work with and the benefits are awesome. Health insurance is crazy cheap for an individual anthem plan and they give you $1,000 to help meet your deductible.
cons: Back to back calls. It's a call center. We call people way too much so a lot of people are rude. Calls get really repetitive.  And when the volume is slow, the ramp up the automated calls and we'll call people for no reason at all. The system always freezes or kicks you out during an order.

review_title: Does not live up to core values
job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Orlando, FL
pros:
PTO accumulation
Schedules
On-site team building activities
cons: This company is focused on numbers only. Integrity is lacking which is scary & they allow and encourage employees to do the bare minimum for patients who are calling for deserved and necessary benefits/meds.

pros: Lots of work, great co-workers, benefits are decent. Different type of business so lots to learn.
cons: Long hours, understaffed, no direction from leadership, favoritism, projects started then stopped halfway through development due to upper management change of direction. Employees treated as numbers instead of humans. Expected to work late nights and weekends. No consideration for employee longevity

job_title: Software Development Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I have spent almost 9 years with the company, and the majority of that time has been very enjoyable and rewarding.  The company has great pay (assuming you land in a department that believes in market adjustments), and most departments offer a fair amount of flexibility.
cons: My biggest personal complaint is the health benefits left little to be desired.  Really the only other thing that bothers me about the company is the wages paid to lower level employees working in call centers and fulfillment centers.  I would like to see the company make more of an effort to increase wages for these folks.

review_title: Work here if you want to get no Training, and don't mind being unfulfilled at the end of the day...
pros: They are very profitable and are growing. Great benefits and working structure. Innovative products which are on the leading edge of the industry. You can do well here if you are a political animal.
cons:
If you're not an MBA or PharmD, your promotion prospects are limited. Your work will be directed by people that don't value your opinion and unless you are in lock-step you'll be singled out as negative or not a "team-player".Some senior management/division heads clearly don't understand the market environment they are working in and don't want to listen to other opinions. You will have to keep chapstik around for all the butts you will have to kiss to get anywhere.

I had no background in PBM and was looking for training. I got virtually none. My first immediate Manager was a nice guy, but was too busy dealing with the fallout from the acquisition of his former company by ESI to train me. I was basically thrown in the deep end and only got about 4 total days of training. Even after almost 2 years I was still trying to learn about the business. Don't expect to learn much - they do not like to share info about how the PBM business works, unless a) they like you or b) you are an "insider" from one of the companies ESI acquired.  Neither applied to me.

Sales are told to make all kinds of promises to prospects but ESI's overburdened IT platform cannot handle the processes. They are heavily dependent on IT and it takes forever to get things fixed, incurring the wrath of the client. The PA Tool (OASIS) was developed by an acquired company. Didn't translate into ESI's platform and they spent months trying to get it to work, but also laid off all the Program Developers who knew the code for the program. When it became clear they made a big mistake, they threw Millions at IT Consultants, trying to backwards engineer the app to get the source codes. 

The company seems happy to spend a couple of Million $ on a company function, but nickel and dime the employees when it comes to raises.

Not a lot of info sharing between departments and it's clear there is resentment between recently acquired company employees and the old ESI folks. Account Management and Sales are always at odds as the AM's rarely visit the clients but the Sales folks get the brunt of the problems that the AM's are supposed to fix, but cannot because the IT issues keep happening. Vicious cycle of the same old problems.

You will be basically an Employee Number to all but your immediate Manager. I got a new Director and he never spoke with me once in 4 months. I was laid off so won't get the chance.

review_title: Medco Had A Good Thing Going
pros: The pay, benefits, and location is good for the time being. That may change, no one seems to know.
cons:
An atmosphere of secrecy looms over the day to day operation. There is no room to grow as an individual and management does not care about you contributions. Submit a simple solution to a productivity problem? You'll be told it's a great idea before you are told to cease development. Even if there was no cost to the company.

Poorly managed doesn't say enough. They announced that we would be starting to use a new software platform which we were told was not finished, had several bugs, and required dozens of work-arounds they already knew about before we even started using it. But here they were all ready to put efficiency, productivity, and customer data on the line with unfinished (and already out-dated) software. Then the day it was supposed to launch we are told there was a problem deploying it and it would be another week. A week goes by and another hiccup stalls their brilliant scheme. Two weeks later we are told it is suspended indefinitely due to major problems. They were willing to knowingly use broken software to run critical portions of the operation involving clinical drug checks, protected patient information, and patient safety. And those of us that would have had to use this to perform our jobs would have been scrutinized and micro-managed for not being able to overcome the glaring problems they gave us. Unacceptable.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: My coworkers are the best thing about that job. I love seeing my friends everyday and they are wonderful, friendly people who make the time more bearable.
cons: The company is so big don't expect to be noticed by management unless someone doesn't like you, then you will always find yourself in a predicament. My manager for 2 years was on my tail so much I got FMLA for stress because of her. When she finally was promoted and I got a new supervisor I was so used to the old way of things I would sneak and hide if I saw her coming while I was on break. I assume it was PTSD from when I was under the dragon lady. What was more unfortunate I think was the fact that there is no check and balance system. When I raised my concerns with HR that she was setting me up to get fired which she was, their response was to tell her what I said and I heard them tell her "You handle it." Needless to say she was not pleased with me after that. The only way I kept my job for the following year while I was still under her was FMLA, remaining stone faced, never spoke to ANYONE and just play dead most of the time. Thinking now how she treated me because I was intelligent and she was threatened by me; it makes me sad and I honestly want to cry about it because I was a great employee and no one above her would check her behavior and now she is upper management.

pros: Benefits are good. Compensation package is above average.
cons: No work/life balance; no resource investment, teams expected to do way more with way less.  No focus or concern for smaller clients.  Unrealistic expectations set by leadership without direction or resources to accomplish project tasks.  Performance rating process is unfair and forces good workers to bottom ratings.

review_title: Dismantling of Medco known as Express-Scripts
pros: Great HQ in St. Louis.................................Nothing further
cons: This organization could be the best if they would invest in Quality, Patient Service and Positive Employee Development.  If you are a former Medco Employee your days are numbered as the whole of Medco employees are being terminated due to higher salaries than the ESI Range.

review_title: There's good and bad but if you have the right attitude, it's not as bad as people make it out to be at ESI! Pay your dues, demonstrate desire to do more and do it well and you will get noticed! It's all in how you conduct yourself. Those giving negative reviews are probably venting due to being wronged by specific personnel but it doesn't mean the company is bad as a whole! There are areas of opportunity as with any company but lots of greatness as well!
pros: Great co workers who are dedicated and care about doing a great job and keeping members happy. The benefits are great and working from home a huge plus!
cons: Getting upper management to listen to those in the trenches on the front line. We may be in the trenches at the bottom of the food chain but we know our jobs and need to be involved in true focus group sessions in which upper management can truly see how it's done. Anyone can manage a department or company but a smart executive will demonstrate a true desire to listen to those who do the job everyday and will value contributions of those on the front line to improve service to clients and their members. Happy employees will be loyal, work even harder!

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Tempe, AZ
pros: convenient location, decent pay & benefits, can use headphones for music
cons: The Mandatory overtime, is extensive and never ending. Always find another reason to extend and continue. Leadership is frequently either passive aggressive or condescending. Pharmacy tech is quite tedious and boring, all they are looking for is a robot. Internal morale is very poor and the company is blind to it, either by choice or ignorance. They will work you to burn out point.

pros: There are a lot of specialized teams and a lot of opportunities to specialize on certain clients or certain types of medications so that you become very stream lined in your job function.  We're offered monthly bonuses based off of productivity and quality scores, so the opportunity for extra money is there if you work hard.  The insurance and benefits are pretty good as well as the discount program offered to us through Abenity where you can save on just about anything you can think of from online shopping to airline miles to car insurance.
cons: The particular call center and department I work in has 18-20 teams, each managed by by a different supervisor.  We have 3 department supervisors and then it continues up the chain from there.  They all have totally different managerial styles and knowledge levels, as well as backgrounds.  That said, with all those different supervisors walking around, you never know what to expect.  One may tell you to handle a case one way and then another will walk up and chastise you for doing it that way.  It gets confusing really fast.  They also all give out different information regarding HR things like attendance, etc.  So you may be sitting next to someone who shows up on time for work once a week and has been out of work unexcused 30 times who has never gotten a write up, while the person on the other side of you has worked for the company 13 years and has a different supervisor and missed 3 days for the first time ever because they had a heart attack and were in intensive care and they got written up.  There's no rhyme or reason to it.  It all seems very unorganized.  Training is not very organized either.

job_title: Depressed Female in New Castle, DE
pros: I would say a job is worth something, but not much else. Most people do work hard there
cons: Very low pay. Too many lies from the top. Growth and expansion are in line, but no matter what, it's never going to change incentives for the employee. No matter how hard you work, it won't add up. If someone needs just a job, then hey this dumps for you. People knock over pills on the nasty floor and reuse them. You need special permission to use the bathroom.  The whole HR process is a nightmare.

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Dublin, OH
pros: Pay and benefits are good, along with opportunity to earn performance bonuses. Option to work at home is excellent. Renovations are currently in progress and added a workout facility to our location, which is an added bonus. Excellent supervisors and open door policy.
cons: Started working with company under Medco Health name, so naturally, there may be certain changes that are not liked. One change is you were given vacation/sick time and now it's "earned" each wee. This makes it more difficult to take vacation earlier in year, unless you hold off from taking vacation one year,  so that it rolls over to the next.

review_title: Great Benefits Package. Lousy Treatment of Employees, though.
job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Great starting hourly pay and benefits package. It was literally the only reason I stayed with them as long as I did.

The PTO (Paid Time Off) system was pretty great.

Cafeteria with great food.

Full access to the built-in gym.

They tend to hire some genuinely awesome individuals to be around.

If you do happen to move up, it's not the worst place to build a foundation for a career.

Most of all...there's really no better feeling in the world than telling a person with a chronic disease that they qualified for assistance and would be getting a $900 medicine for free. Seriously. Best part of the job.
cons:
In my division, the managers absolutely refused to take accountability for many things. Also, if a customer needed or demanded to speak to one on the phone, it was very much like pulling a tooth, if they didn't refuse altogether.

The position I worked could sometimes be really emotionally draining. You spend all day talking to ill people who can sometimes be really angry and you just have to be their punching bag because of their situation.

Your division could be closed and you could be laid off at any time with next to no advance notice. Unless you've worked your way up, you're expendable and you have to always remember that.

The system for calling off of work is WAY too complicated.

High turnover.

Mandatory Saturday Meetings. If you can't get a babysitter, well, too bad.

No designated smoking area, so get ready to spend five minutes of your fifteen minute break walking off of the property for a puff.

If you're in an accident and have to take a leave of absence due to being physically unable to work, letters from your physican explaining why it's literally not physically possible for you to work apparently means very little to management.

pros: Benefits, you receive a paycheck every two weeks and you work with some great people.
cons: Weak/incompetent leadership, disorganized processes, inconsistent standard operating procedures, technology/software constantly going down, no work-life balance, no chance for advancement unless you are in the 'good old boys' club. No reimbursement for licensing fees.

pros: Flexible schedules, decent resume building potential if you put in effort, it's a job that pays you decent (not the best pay for Phoenix area pbm. I'd advise to get in and get out)
cons: It's like high school, a lot of clique networks, trash talking and gossip. It's not unusual for supervisors and leads to have relationships with lower level techs. Express scripts' internal culture is typical office politics, it's about who you know and not your skills - you will not advance if someone on the 'inside' network doesn't want you to have that position. There are people in upper management who got their jobs the same way, which creates a lot of messes throughout every level of the company. CEO George Paz was too cheap and destroyed the company's reputation, which is why so many client contracts are not being renewed. Current CEO Tim Wentworth is a Theater graduate and running a pharmaceutical company, that should tell you enough. ESI is under several legal messes and layoffs, while many employees go into work everyday with barely enough work because ESI is 'overstuffed' = more layoffs on the way. Instability is ESI's moto. They're quick to hire, quick to fire, quick to ruin something good (it's cyclic at ESI for things to be good, upper management wants to make 'changes', changes make everything a disasterous mess, they boot the bulk of the 'change' and things get good again, repeat). Jump ship before it's too late, I don't see DOD renewing their contract with ESI because they've dropped the ball too many times. Through all the messes and treating employees like garbage, CEOs and executives still get paid their base salary of millions on top of their 7 figure bonuses.

job_title: Patient Care Advisor in Fairfield, OH
pros: The pay is excellent for younger people looking to get started and they do promote within from what I had seen while working there. They're generally fair with benefits if it's absolutely your only resource to them and they do offer a decent amount of PTO for their employees. They're also generally agreeable when it comes to missed days and time off so long as you give notice ahead of time.
cons: As I said, great position for younger folk just starting out, weather or not your supervisors believe that. The real problem with the company falls on the supervisors. It's not ENTIRELY their fault as I believe some just had poor training and were put into positions they weren't entirely ready to take on, however that isn't exactly an excuse because the regular employee suffers from the lack of adequate assistance and understanding. Most just seem over-worked and under-qualified for their position.  There's also the extreme issue of favoritism and it seems that some can get away with hardly working while they'll crack down on people who meet their daily quota when they decide you aren't taking the position as seriously as they'd like. It's not a particularly hard or serious job. Most of your work will be simple clerical things and it'll definitely feel more like customer service than anything else they tell you.  It's a job at the end of the day, there are good and bad parts and it's no worse than any retail job you can get. Just don't put too many eggs in the 'Express Scripts' basket. It's not a career.

pros: Helping patients achieve their goal to have a baby
cons: Burnt out very fast, pay is not good for techs, unrealistic expectations

review_title: Ok company to start at but not to stay for long
job_title: Data Entry and Pharmacy Technician  in Bensalem, PA
pros: Easy to get a job with decent pay.
cons: The supervisors play favorism and treat the workers unfairly. Hard time to take off and unfair rules where you can't take off during the week before or the week after a holiday or you don't get holiday pay. Union rep treat union part time worker as unimportant. They try their best to eliminate any overtime and barely gives bonuses compared to when I first started in 2001.

review_title: Stable Employment for Successful Company - Rare in an Uncertain Economy
job_title: Pharm Tech in Maryland Heights, MO
pros: Good benefits, medical and prescription benefit,, dental, vision ins. , decent hours, fast, tuition assistance, accumulation of PTO time off, coaching helps improve knowledge and skills, several weeks of extensive training, the satisfaction of helping people.
cons: Pressure of being judged by metrics, numbers... lack of preparation for handling automated calls and complaints about automated calls, being expected to rush from one call to next, even when systems are working slowly can be stressful. Pay could be better.

review_title: A cold and dead end position for those over 30 and not interested in "after hours hobnobbing"
pros: Desk job, great if you are in management and can get into the "inner circle", staff employees have a narrow area of responsibilities to focus, technology is available, regular pay, set schedule
cons: staff is treated impersonally, all business decisions are made with no regard to staff and staff needs, it's all about the bottom line - no attempt at staff or customer satisfaction

review_title: This is a very good company to work for but I do not like the responsibilities of my job.
pros:
-Company is very profitable.
-Benefits are very good.
-Good professional expirences
-They develop their people if they work hard.
-Good incentive programs.
cons: There is a parental metaphor that I have noticed between management and employees.  Employees are treated like children even  if they are professionals working in an office environtment.  Once someone gets into management they are upgraded to "adult" status.  This has been frustrating for me as a person who wants to be treated equitabally but can't unless I go into management.

job_title: Rph Drone in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Health benefits retirement program base pay package . Many good people and friendships made over time. High turnover rate means plenty of jobs available at all times
cons: Horrible company to work for. They only care about numbers. Will spend millions to watch key strokes but forget about getting a new mouse pad.  Don't make your numbers you get fired. Make your numbers and goals will be increased next year. Try to practice pharmacy or help a patient and you will quickly find this  behavior is discouraged by short sighted management

review_title: Horrible place to work after buying Medco!
pros: Benefits are good and depending on your position you can work from home
cons: WORK LIFE BALANCE!  I spent more time working than being with my family, even after hours the expectation was to be available for clients. I was working 70+ hours a week when I left and that was not good enough for management. ESI was a great place to work until they bought Medco- all downhill from there. Management looks for any little thing to mark you threshold and not give you a raise or bonus.

review_title: Medco Health was better before it merged with Express Scripts.
job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Dublin, OH
pros: weekly pay, overtime, great employees, advancement opportunities, team environment
cons: Metrics used to determine bonuses, Vacation time earned not given, time in service doesnt matter.

job_title: Pharmacy Production Clerk in Whitestown, IN
pros: Easy work, laid back environment with friendly people. Able to listen to an mp3 player device. First shift has a proper manager and runs smoothly. Raise based on work and attitude. Decent benefits.
cons: Boring and repetitive work, terrible organization on second shift.

pros: Salary and some benefits, maybe
cons: I worked for Express Scripts for over 14 years. Work  load was overwhelming and highly stressful but management didn't care enough to acquire additional employees which added more pressure.  Teams didn't communicate with each other on specific joint projects.  Communication between management and employees was very poor to say the least.

pros: A large organization . Therefore, you can transfer to other desirable location should you wish to do so. They will recognize your efforts locally should you be a hard worker.
cons: Highly political all in who you know and who like you in order to be promoted. Top management is really close, and if you did not start with them or attended the same University as most of them you can forgot be noticed.

review_title: I would rather be back at wal-mart
pros: I have to admit that some of the people I work with are pleasant to work with and make the day go by faster.
cons:
I was hired under the impression that I'd be doing one job and then that was changed during training. I was trained to do what I was initially hired to do then my supervisor added 3x more work on programs that even the trainer himself didn't know. Everyone on the "team" was supposed to be crossed train on everything but there's only one or 2 people that actually are trained on everything. And being trained on multiple programs doesn't equal higher pay, just more stress of keeping all the information straight. For my "team" it's not a matter of data entry on mulitple programs. My job requires me to take calls and do data entry for mulitple programs at the same time.


While the job itself can be gratifying, the work itself is not worth the stress.  Time off doesn't come easy to get a break from the stress. In order to get anything more than a day off, you almost have to ask months in advance. That is if you know that far in advance that you need time off. If you get sick or your kid gets sick, sure you can get time off but it's going to cost you "attendance points." Get too many of those from either having an unplanned absence or you get stuck in traffic so you're late or have to leave early, and you're done.


I left a job in a Walmart pharmacy for this job and I have regretted it more and more everyday since I quit. I was at the point of not wanting to even get out of bed for work when I worked at Walmart but I would take that job with those customers back any day as long as I could get away from Express Scripts. What does that say?

pros:
It is a large company, which offers some piece of mind, average to above health 
insurance but costs $$, hours are good, and time off can be flexible.  The company is
full of Good people to work with, who try to do a good job for our patients.
cons:
The company sets strictly enforced rate expectations for Pharmacist and 
Technicians that are mostly unattainable without cutting corners.  If 
you are making corrections or needing to clarify something or spending 
more than average time with a patient or doctor's office on the phone 
then it will make it more difficult to achieve the expected rate.  This 
puts us in a compromising position, where job security is threatened at 
the expense of potentially decreasing patient safety, and or not 
fulfilling patient/client expectations.  This is a perfect storm in an 
environment where there are fewer and fewer jobs available.  There has 
been significant increases in efficiency's deserving of praise, but only
 met with higher rate expectations and threats.  This company appears 
not to appreciate its workers, and have stripped away the pride that 
many used to have in their work.  At the end of the day I am 
increasingly left with the feeling that I didn't do the best job for the
 patient and deliver what their insurance is paying for and expecting.  
There is also very little if any company sponsored events for employees 
outside work hours.

review_title: Crazy amounts of bureaucracy and jumping through hoops just to jump through hoops until the next reorg.
pros: Coworkers are great, some managers are good, pay and benefits are top notch.
cons:
Getting anything done without a committee
Getting anything done collaboratively (i.e. committees don't count)
personal growth, manager feedback, visibility, stability, encouragement, personal empowerment

review_title: vey dissatisfied with the direction of the company.
pros: Depends on the group, but very flexible with a work  schedule.
cons: Letting go some very valuable staff members all in the name of budget cuts and then doubling up the work load for those that are  left.   Moving a lot of positions to St. Louis.   No loyalty.

job_title: Senior Product Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
I started at Express Scripts as an intern 8 years ago. I graduated during the Great Recession, and my boss from my internship made sure to find a place for me to begin my career. Once I landed a full time job, I soon began to explore how I could combine my passion of service and desire to lead. I spoke to HR and was able to create my own service group that gave back to the local community and gave me experience in leading a team to prepare me for my hopeful future of one day being a people leader. I have since evolved this group to expand its focus on professional growth and networking, and Express Scripts has added this to his Employee Resource Group offering. My leaders have always been supportive of my extracurricular work and see it has a competitive edge.

Express Scripts has an entrepreneurial spirit and challenges all employees to come up with ideas that will continue to push the company to excellence. INCUB8, the Shark Tank of Express Scripts, was an awesome competition that allowed employees to pitch their ideas to senior leaders and have the opportunity for their idea to be chosen to be funded and receive a monetary reward.
cons:
Depending on your department work/life balance can be difficult to attain at times. I find that being honest with myself and my leaders combined with working smarter has helped me to keep a health work life balance. 

I also think that with having a workforce that is 70% female we should have a more robust maternity policy allowing new mothers to have full pay for the 12 weeks of leave.

pros:
Nice people
Many positions posted - Not easily attainable 
Nice offices
Great lunch - Sodexo
Great 401k
Nice PTO
Workout facility
cons:
HR is way too political and limits the growth of great employees. They use things like "number of years" to tell you exactly where you need to be in the company. You can't go from F to H because you skipped G. 

Express Scripts wants to empower the employee (they say), but what they do is really do whatever they can to put you into a system where you go to work everyday, give it your best, go home, and get a marginal raise at the end of the year. If you have a desire to jump the ladder quickly and not be a 50 year old person sitting in a cube, or if you have a desire to move around the company (horizontally) and experience everything the company has to offer, this company isn't for you. You will be limited, unless you know a VP personally. 

The rating system is crazy - as it gives your manager the ability to determine whether you deserve a 2%, 3% or 4% raise. If you can prove you did an amazing job, your boss can come back and say "you didn't collaborate enough", or "you aren't aligned enough" which in turn sets your "stretch" rating down to a "target" rating... meaning you are getting a shorted raise/bonus.

The company pinches pennies, and some managers take it upon themselves to pinch the pennies you might have forgotten to pinch. 

Fun fact about PTO - they will pay you for your PTO, but if you don't give a full 2 weeks notice before resigning, they don't pay you. A two week notice is a nice thing the employee does for the employer, but they use the two weeks notice to strong arm you into providing it. Seems like legal theft to me.

review_title: Not a long term option, low pay
job_title: Business Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great people to work with had a very nice manager who has unfortunately quit now,  401k health benefits nice office place and cafeteria, free snacks and coffee
cons: No training at all, upper management loves to micromanage every aspect of department, pay is super low for years of experience, does not care about employees or team morale, high school like drama in department, no WFH

pros: I have been working with ESI for over 2 years in our virtual site of Valdosta. Yes there are of changes and with those changes comes positive outcomes. Is there some things we can help change to make costumer service better, yes. Are there changes that can be implemented to the virtual cites that can make our jobs better, yes. But in order to make those changes we need to be heard. Our voices count too. And yes so.stones I feel as if it doesn't because you have to prove that the problem exist. And that is the hardest part if the job. Aa an employee I have learned how to help my members not just by listening but relating to their situations. I always tell myself that you have to be patient and listen in order to be able to understand your member and their concerns. I truly believe that ESI HAS AND WILL continue to bring changes to the members and clients they represent. We as a whole company have to take time and have open communication to make the system work for both call centers, management, virtual cites so we can be 100 % CSR FOR OUR MEMBERS. Great benefits, great pay,excellent bonuses all are great. But educating the member about who we are and what we can do is more important. I learned as a member through my employment what my insurance benefits has to offer me in order for my health to say it's course. I thank God Daily for what I do here on my job. Even though my system can go down. I just would like to help make a difference in my virtual community for me and for my fellow PCAS
cons: Downtime and please stop thinking ISP IS OUR FAILURE. Its not. Nor is our system. How flow of traffic is routed

job_title: Senior Engineering Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: What can I say Express Scripts has really turned things around.  I joined the company with a lot of anxiety and now that I have been here a while I absolutely love my job.  No seriously I turned down Google for an engineering manager interview today without thinking.  The company is really promoting an engineering culture that is obsessed with automation and doing things right rather than quick.   They have removed roadblocks on new technology, and  compliance that you typically see in huge fortune 100 companies.  Schedules are quite flexible depending on your manager.  The projects are very interesting especially as we transform with lots of ability to really make an impact quickly.  Embracing agile has promoted work life balance (if you want that) or if you want to work more projects you can get involved with other teams.
cons: There is lots and lots of ambiguity meaning that you have to be quite good at just driving in a direction and expecting that you may have to backtrack.  Building an engineering culture is hard especially when you are dealing with the past leadership teams mistakes that allowed the company to be known as one of the worst to work for. The company is still heavily network driven, ensure that you are promoting technical leadership rather than the good old boys style of leadership that earned us the worst company title.  Be wary of transformation hold outs, if you interview ask heavily about what the team is doing to embrace the transformation.  If they don't know what your talking about I would run the other direction.  Oh yeah there's also only 6 holidays which is terrible, but 20 days PTO so oh well.

pros: Growth industry = Stability. Good reputation as and industry leader. Concentrates on maintaing stockholder interest.
cons: Work life balance, unjustified promotions for retention purposes versus performance rating. Budgets are unreasonably lean and impossible to manage. They want for you to accomplish A-Z but only want to give you a fraction of the resources and finances in order to accomplish the desired end result.

review_title: Excellent experience for starting out, not so much for growing
job_title: Senior IT Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Short Version:

* Ability to change jobs/departments very easily
* "Flat" organization - everyone is in the trenches together (in IT, at least)
* Good camaraderie (up to a point)
* Nice headquarters facility
* Clear focus - save $$$
* Good bonuses

Longer version:

Express Scripts was a great place to learn how large company IT can work.  I had the opportunity to work with a multitude of departments and people and got a lot out of that.  It really makes a difference whether you are in a good organization or one that is struggling - in the former, you get the resources you need to succeed while in the latter it is a sisyphean effort.  Colleagues tend to look out for each other, despite being ranked against each other for raises, bonuses and promotions.  Every day could be a new challenge so if you like moving quickly this is a great fit, for a while...
cons:
Short Version:

* Very limited promotion ability.  It is highly unlikely to get more than one in your career at ESI.
* Always oncall - the only times I did not receive calls, emails, and text messages was when I was flying.  Though it is not required to always be available, that is the general expectation.
* Good people "disappear" while poor performers linger for years (and harm the culture)
* Saving money leads to poor outcomes (but everyone acts like this is unexpected)
* Force-ranking of all employees
* Bonuses can be and are canceled entirely due to factors outside of your control (i.e. you can perform excellently but, due factors entirely out of your control, you receive nothing).

Longer Version:

At some point most employees notice that the problems we have today have the same root cause as those we had the year before, and the year before that.  Chronic rushing and underfunding of IT projects has led to a situation where IT has little credibility with the business and individual employees do not have much to be proud of.  As managers, you are expected to promote the strategies and decisions made by senior leadership, despite the fact that "in the trenches" we and our teams have to deal with the fallout.  The force-ranking is a real problem.  Why ESI still does it while many other companies quietly eliminate these systems is baffling, but with the rapid turnover in our HR department my only conclusion is that the CEO likes the system.  Expect to be hung out to dry if you have a public mistake in the last three months of the year and, if you want to do something that will make you a top ("stretch") performer make sure that it is public and, again, in the last three months of the year (earlier than that and it will likely be forgotten).

review_title: Business needs come first, your needs not a consideration
pros: Good benefits, instant vesting of company share of 401k match. For the level of education needed to be hired, pay is better than working in a retail store and it's an indoor sit down job. If you are a young worker who can attend college and better yourself and maintain the work schedule here, it's a good job. If you are older and have been downsized from a higher paid career that has no chance of coming back, at least the benefits here are good, and you have a comfortable environment, there are not many job choices out there.
cons: Very hard to get approved time off, even with time in bank, you might get approved for Tues, Wed, Thurs off and get 2 attendance occurrences for Mon and Fri if you plan a real vacation.(and you must remember to call in sick those days or face firing for no call no show). Within department, people who perform fewer job tasks and have not been trained in handling more complicated accounts end up with more overtime and higher bonuses, seems backwards to me, these people basically have a simpler job.

review_title: Good place to start... don't stay
pros: Very fast-moving company, very successful, probably going to stay around for a while. Good benefits and pay (for a while). Senior management are approachable and don't talk down.
cons: Advancement depends on who likes you and can be arbitrary. It'll be very slow compared to job-hopping (like a 10% pay bump max), so pay will lag behind. Some positions have extreme workloads. IT help is terrible... you can be without a computer for days. Hope you don't have work to do.

pros: It is a fairly easy job taking customer calls.The pay will now be the same as other customer service jobs in the same field.
cons: This company only looks for cost savings and does not handle situations logically. I previously worked for Medco before Express Scripts purchased them and Medco paid a much higher salary, had better benefits and was more concerned with getting things handle properly as opposed to looking out for profits first then the patient.

pros: Hard to say since most of the interaction with ESI was not positive as they let a lot of people from Medco go.
cons: Don't seem very on top of their numbers and metrics. Targets appear to be moving targets. From what I could tell most long-time ESI employees were reluctant to bring up bad news. The deilverer of bad news did not seem like they had long to be there.

review_title: Can't Understand the Low Rating, Best Co. I've Worked For
pros: It's easy to move up within the company. Management is very positive and helpful.  Great benefits and great 401K as they match 6%.  You can also purchase company stock at an 8% discount.  They are very understanding that you have a life outside of work and are very flexible with schedules.
cons: Sometimes the wrong people get promoted.  Technology provided to customers is limited.  Within the company the IT department or software seems to need an upgrade.

pros: I honestly can't really think of any pros  They don't want good honest people working for them.
cons: health care companies should not be run by engineers.  They don't understand that healthcare has actual people at the end of the line receiving the medication.  This is not a car factory and there needs to be attention to the patient and clients.  This being said I understand it is a business and needs to make money however there are millions of patients we service that are not getting the best customer service.  We have thousands of pharmacists working for this company and they feel their hands are tied.  Trying to do right by patients and trying to meet numbers to keep their jobs.

job_title: Account Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great coworkers, new buildings, decent pay if coming from outside the company (internal increases are very low), benefits, many opportunities for advancement and work from home opportunities.
cons: High turnover across all management level, the company has no consistency, no work life balance and no employee loyalty. Company uses being an at will employer as a crutch for mass lay offs and unfair treatment.

job_title: Prior Auth Representative in Dublin, OH
pros:
-Decent pay
-Opportunity for benefits
-Reasonable time off system
cons:
-Consistency was a huge issue across the board. Constantly changing standard operating procedure and out-of-touch management team will have you feeling around in the dark when it comes to learning new material, affecting sense of job security. Promised a particular work schedule and pay when hired, but upper management changed both over course of four week training. Singular work function paired with low work volume and inconsistent internet policy means sitting for hours with nothing to do.
-Poor work site upkeep. Weekly complaints of flies and bedbugs (regularly being caught and shown to management) puts employees on edge.
-Don't expect management or human resources to advocate for employees. Reasonably disagreeing with people in management doesn't bode well, even if they are wrong.

job_title: Data Entry Technician in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Environment can be very chill and friendly. Once you get the system down its easy to get through the day.
cons: Although the program changes are easy to adapt to sometimes they're too frequent and the work can become redundant really fast. The micromanaging is very off-putting. Some employees try colors show when opportunities arise for advancement. productivity goals are often raised before the original ones are met.

pros: Thus far, ESI is a great  company. I am in the beginning phase of training and I must say the training is second to none. ESI seems very organized and eager to keep their business going by hiring top notch individuals. Very very engaged management and an awesome President. I look forward to advancing my career at ESI.
cons: Personal cons for me at the time would only be schedule, but being that work from home it should be no problem working around it.

pros: Competitive Salary & benefits.  PRN
cons:
Minimal training on medications to be administered
Poor training in the field
More interested in a 'warm body with an RN license' than pt care & safety 
Pts visits scheduled before all training/documentation completed, i.e: BLS, PPD.
Pts load substantially greater than advised
Passive/aggressive management, particularly is pt care concerns are voiced.
NOTE:  if you value your RN license be very cautious with this company.

pros: Insurance benefits, close to home, lots of restaurants to go to for the allowed 30min lunch you receive, nice updated building .
cons: Managers,supervisors,leads, micromanaging and work load exceptions. No respect for employees, management Un knowledge of the work being done, management Favoritism training classes are useless and waste of time for the staff.

review_title: demoralizing, dehumanizing, and could care less about their patients.
pros: I receive a paycheck which I am grateful for as the job market is soft and there is nowhere else to go.
cons: Raised production numbers at same time down-graded systems and job tools so it feels like we are set up to fail. Mandates overtime with less than 24 hours notice, while numbers do not support it. When only requesting overtime sign-up threatens with mandate through email multiple times a day. Tries to get us to use our sick days when we are turned down for vacation days. Dismal work environment.

review_title: Lack of focus on quality and employees--it's all about the money
pros: I have been with Esi (formerly Medco) for 5 years. It is very close to home and very relaxed environment. Wearing jeans to work daily is a definite plus.   Since the merger, there has been some improvement in reducing the non clinical work that is given to Rph's. That is a pro in some cases, but is causing lack of quality in others.
cons: As others have mentioned, customer service is just lip service. The focus on customer service has declined greatly since the merger, and patients complain about it all the time. The quality of service given to our patients is so low, all we can do is remain quiet when the patients are upset, even though we agree with them wholeheartedly.  The lack of respect for pharmacists and clinical judgement is laughable. While Medco was a very forward thinking, clinical type of PBM, ESI is only about saving money and making sure it's stock is valuable. Therefore things that Medco figured out a long time ago regarding quality, compliance and customer service are being ignored, and in effect, things are going backward. If we do something wrong, we are expected to somehow let the patient feel it is their fault. I have tried to be optimistic since the merger, but am quickly realizing things are going in the wrong direction. It's very disappointing.

review_title: Sr. Management in panic over falling stock price
job_title: Business Analyst in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: Should receive a severance package soon
cons:
Rated the 2nd worst company in America to work for by the Wall Street Journal.
Employee feedback on company survey was so negative, the results were never published.
Merger with Medco is a disaster, way too costly and way behind schedule, heads will roll.
Cash flow is starting to be a huge problem.
