Rapidly losing membership lives to private exchanges.
Sr. Management starting to panic since they were told they will held directly responsible for the poor results now, not lower level employees.
Since they can't grow revenues, they must cut expenses which means mass layoffs by year end.
Franklin Lakes building is too costly, trying to get rid of at any cost.

job_title: Technical Communicator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Some of the managers (such as the one I worked with) are smart, forward-thinking, and hard-working.
cons: There are people in the company that made me wonder how in the world they ever got their jobs. I've never seen so many clueless people gathered in one place!

review_title: Aggressive culture but no work prioritization
job_title: Senior Business Systems Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Great for go-getters, lots of projects/initiatives to sink their teeth into
They truly want to fulfill the mission of fast/accurate prescriptions
The culture likes innovation and getting things done
cons:
If you have 5 things on your plate they are all top priority (and you clearly don't have enough to do!)
Leadership tramples on workers to accomplish the company's goals
Run-and-gun environment; getting it done trumps pausing to think how to do it better

pros:
Flexible work environment with the right manager. 
Fast-paced, interesting work.
Friendly people who tend to listen to all levels of meeting participants.
Ability to make a difference quickly due to many fire drills and rapid changes.
cons:
Many, many fire drills and changes including re-organizations and layoffs.
Benefits are so-so, but bonuses are good.
Per other reviews, it is important to be supported by people who have influence.

pros: Large corporation, predictable, array of benefits and services.
cons: Do less with more mentality, low cost model, hard work and long hours expected. Can be high stress. Don't reward long term employees. Salaries are typically below average for level of contribution. Let talent leave to replace with younger, cheaper staff. You are a spoke on the giant wheel---easily replaceable.

review_title: Great for starting not for staying
job_title: Insurance Verification Lead in Orlando, FL
pros: Good benefits including tuition reimbursement. On site lunch cafe. Workout room.
cons: Hard to get noticed in order to move up. Team managers micromanage and like to flaunt power at times. Everything is about numbers and it makes you realize that healthcare is a monopoly game too. Pay isn't that great but the added benefits help.

review_title: Ok company, looks more for quality than quality, disorganized company, lots of 3rd party companies under esi
pros: Ok pay and benefits due to union, good pto than most. schedule doesn't change. Bonus every month which depends on your quality (quality checks from 3rd party vendor -con).
cons: Lots of change to processes makes work difficult, Disorganized company, lack of communication with different departments and sites. Pay is ok but can pay better for the job. Some Low level grunts are doing Sr manager work if your intelligent which leads to no compensation or recognition. A few third party companies under esi.

review_title: Amazing changes in past two years
pros: For the past couple years Tim Wentworth and his leadership team have been focused on improving the culture and making this a better place to work. One of his first actions as CEO was to allow everyone to dress casually this summer. Improving the culture in a company focused on patients makes me look forward to coming in every day.
cons: Healthcare operates on slim margins, so we have to be focused on every dollar we spend everyday.

review_title: Pay and benefits is not always worth it
job_title: Pharmacy Production Clerk in Whitestown, IN
pros: Friendly coworkers, If you like overtime this is a good place to be, very consistent at giving you your breaks and lunch, pays well for the job you are working
cons: when hired was not told about the mandatory overtime. Was told an occasional Saturday. No actual sick time. If you happen to fall sick you are pointed for each day unless you have a doctors note and then one point for every 5 days. But lets face it, who has the money to run to the doctor every time they are sick. If you have kids you better have a good back up plan because if something comes up unexpected and you cannot make it, you can call in, but you are pointed. The system only allows for so many people to be off at ounce so even if you do ask for a day off in advance, with enough PTO they can turn you down and you have to take a point. Also for holiday pay, you have to be there the day before and the day after or you don't get it and you cannot be a minute late. I literally mean a minute! On top of that the micromanaging, never knowing for sure how much overtime you are going to have to work, the constant changing of rules, and depending on what position you apply for you automatically have to go to second shift.

review_title: Great place but expect to manage management
job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Saint Louis, MO
pros: You have a great health benefit package and a very low cost to you. You have a full time job, with seldom mandatory time off. You acquire 6 hours of PTO per week and you can request that time online. Bonus' are based on performance. I was number 1 in my department, got about a 800 bonus every 4 weeks.
cons: The call center space is bigger than a football field. You will have a small cubicle and work in a row of about 15 other techs. They are very strict about little things, because management does not know how to manage in a way that increases production. Don't think this is your easy hourly job. Anytime you leave your desk you must be using your 30 minutes of allotted time for break. The sups can see when you are not at your desk and in production and you can get written up for being even a minute late. You will be on the phone all day, so if doing repetitive things are not for you then this is not the job. One of the biggest cons is the Pharmacy Tech license. Although the tech transcribe Rx's there is NO REQUIREMENT TO BE NATIONALLY CERTIFIED to work here. So if you ever want a different Pharmacy Tech job you will have to obtain that national certification. This is something that Express Scripts does not offer nor do they encourage, because no one is actually required (at the aforementioned pay grade) to get that training. I've seen people write the wrong directions on an Rx (without out any training mind you) and be fired.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Marys, GA
pros:
**The company has awesome health care benefits that they offer you from the start of your employment. They even take an entire day of your training to review the many options that they have in regards to health care. 

**They have implemented a new bonus program that awards PCA's a monetary bonus that they can earn every two weeks based in their post-call survey scores and also completing alerts on a members accounts (which are worth $.15 per point and rack up fast!) 

** You earn paid time off on every single check, and you can schedule paid days off based on your balance. Holiday pay$$$

**Opportunities for growth and development. You receive frequent coachings that help to guide you in becoming more efficient in your calls. Many people are able to move up within the first 6 months.

**Future PCAs - when I was researching this company prior to accepting the job offer I wish someone had gave me honest insight on how stressful it really was. This job is SO stressful. I literally dread coming in every day, but on the first call that I can resolve, that dread starts to dissolve.  This job can be VERY rewarding, especially when you are able to resolve a patient's issues and they tell you that you are doing a good job. 

BUT if you are looking to just collect a paycheck without having to apply yourself, I promise you that this job is not for you.
cons:
**This job is not for everyone! I went home on my first day and bawled my eyes out because it was so stressful and I felt like I would never be able to become efficient on the phones and navigating the accounts. (I DID EVENTUALLY CATCH ON THOUGH!)  If you are the type of person that will crack under pressure, this will not be a good job for your mental or physical health! People can get very upset (understandably) because we are handling their prescriptions and sometimes there are delays with them receiving them which can be life threatening!

**Frequent changes in operating procedure. If you dislike change, this will not be a good fit for you.

pros: Insurance benefits are good.  People are friendly.
cons: Way more is expected than can be done in a ten hour day. Have to use weekends to try and stay caught up with all of the reports and tasks.

review_title: Employed with this company 2 years so far
pros: Working from the comfort of your home, Vto(Voluntary Time Off) only offered if calls are slow and a lot of people are working.
cons: Pay sucks! The lil $0.30 raise each year sucks. You won’t even make $500 a week after taxes and insurance comes out. They hype up the fact of giving out bonuses every month, but that’s based upon how the members grade you on the survey at the end of each call. Even if you served/helped the member doesn’t mean they’ll score you high. So bonuses aren’t  gauranteed. However, when you do get a bonus on the last check of the month you’ll notice it was basically ate up from taxes. I honestly only work here for the health insurance benefits because it’s the only benefit I see benefiting me. You’ll also meet with your supervisor every week or so to go over and grade a call. The meetings  makes you feel like a student meeting with a teacher to search for any little thing you did wrong or anything you can do better. They are currently added new systems and all and they expect you to do more work with no type of pay increase. I notice it’s mostly minority women that work for this company or at least at the bottom of the totem pole. There is no room for growth. The RTL’s which are what I call the fake supervisors are who we send the members to if they ask for a sup. Some of them take it too serious and actually think they are sups when I’m fact their pay says otherwise. From my calculations if they start you with $12.00hr it would take 10+years just to get to $15hr.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Benefits are ok. The deductible is high but the actual cost of the insurance isn’t bad. I’m not sure how Cigna’s takeover will effect this
cons: The training was a joke. The pay is not enough for what is expected of you. In interviews and training they act like it’s all just one big family and that patients were the priority over everything. All lies. As soon as training is over management completely changes their personalities and the only thing they care about is the bottom line and since Cigna took over, the quality of patient care has all but disappeared. That is not what I signed up for

pros: Large company, good health benefits & it's a job
cons: The company is focused on money, to the point that the patients are cheated. Production numbers have increased as moral falls to the pits of hell. Advancement is limited unless you are apart of the "in crowd".  Local HR department is of no help & job posting may list for a few hours before they disappear. Some positions are created for select employees. Bonuses were cut, point system was put in place on a computer system that is slow! Those who make more than $40, 000 do little & the pharmacist with the exception of few feel entitled!  Run for your life!!!!

review_title: Could be worse, could be a lot better!
job_title: Salaried Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Decent pay and health insurance coverage. Fast paced, growing company. Opportunities to advance if you're willing to give up more personal time.
cons: Company grew too fast and doesn't have policies in place. Lack of work life balance.  Everyone is focused on themselves due to forced ranking.  No real perks.

job_title: Prior Authorization in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The job is fairly simple and the location is neutral. Large organization, offers 401K and tuition reimbursment. Monthly bonuses
cons: To move to a different position, its all about who you know and brown nosing. Prior auth department has daily changes, which causes employes to be prone to errors which effects evaluations and bonuses. Micro manage too much, feels like a prison at times.

job_title: Senior Intervention Technician in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great pay/benefits/PTO & multiple schedule choices. If you show up & do your work you have no worries! The culture is getting better & the company is very diverse!!
cons: Everything thing you do is measured by efficiency(which some of the rates they set can be difficult to hit) shrink (time spent at work & not working.) It can be difficult to advance within the company. Management can tend to be micromanaging.

review_title: Run like you saw a ghost
job_title: Project Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
- Innovative technology in operations
- Care about national healthcare cost
- Up to par with new pharmaceutical trends, government regulation and drug pricing
- Competitive pay in the area
cons:
- Make a lot of serious patient safety issues (Class 1 errors)
- Poor processes - some of the processes are questionable with patient safety
- Poor documentation
- Extremely dull HR and IT practices
- Doesn't allow people to move up - I don't see any evidence encouraging lateral moves if your department is restructuring
- Senior managements show favoritism and make decisions personally (instead of professionally)
-  Benefit package is average, but below par compared to other Forbes 100 companies

review_title: IT Business Analyst / IT Application Release Manager
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Benefits were pretty good and met some of the nicest people. Made some good friends over the course of the years worked.
cons: Spent a lot of time working through lunches and/or eating at desk. Too many meetings back to back.

pros: Benefits, benefits, benefits. Express Scripts has one of the best benefit packages that I have ever seen. From Tuition Assistance to Prescription Drug benefits, it is hard to beat.
cons: Very demanding work pace. The loss of caring leadership in the past two years are apparent to the people that haver been there for a long time. A lot of new employees have been rushed through thee pipeline, that the service is suffering.

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Dublin, OH
pros: The work is steady and the company stable. The salary is comparable to most call centers in the Columbus Ohio area and better than some. The benefits are fairly good but I only need single benefits so the cost would be different for a family.They have one important benefit for me and that is tuition reimbursement so you can finish college.
cons: The schedules are varied and new employees generally work nights and weekends.

review_title: Renewed focus on talent and culture
job_title: Senior Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Express Scripts is a high-energy, fast-paced company. That isn't changing, but within the last year there has been a clear pivot to refocus on investing in talent and creating a culture where employees feel valued and have opportunity to meet their career goals.
cons: Not necessarily a con, but all about fit - if you don't enjoy working in a fast-paced environment where priorities can shift regularly, Express Scripts may not be the right place for you.

pros: ESI has been undergoing a transformation in the past couple of years.  It wasn't easy but it is getting better by the day.  There's a new energy around new ideas and projects.  There's greater flexibility for employees and more communication with leadership and employee engagement.
cons: Like any big company, there are departments and managers that could be better.  There are great departments doing great work so find the right place for yourself.

pros: The co-workers (not supervisors or higher ups) are great people and good to work with as you are all going through the same thing.
cons: For about 2-3 years we have been voted in the top 3 of worst companies to work for and for very good reason. The work to life ratio is not good. If you have children they also seem to frown upon that if you have to leave because there is something wrong with your child. They expect you to be available for work even when you aren't scheduled and it's all about numbers.

job_title: Senior Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: As basic as it sounds, it's the people. I've been here 10+ years and the main reason I stay is because I have friends at work. I've been able to grow my career and be challenged like I never thought I could be. You are given a lot of autonomy and the opportunity to make mistakes, safely. The flexibility to work from home has grown tremendously as well. I love the innovation and at the end of the day, I can say I'm contributing to making healthcare better.
cons: Systems are outdated. Lean and mean is definitely the mentality.

review_title: This company has lots of potential for improvement.
job_title: Information Systems in Tennessee City, TN
pros:
PTO earnings are good.
Travel opportunities, if you enjoy travel.
Lots of open positions, because everyone is leaving.
cons:
This company needs work/life balance.
Non-management employees are overworked and under appreciated.
The yearly review program/process stinks.
Money is the driver for EVERYTHING with ESI

review_title: Wish it was a better place to work
pros: PTO time accural, don't have to drive far to work,
cons:
Do not know if you will have a job in January. No job opportunities for Legacy ESI employee's but tons of opportunities for Legacy Accredo employee's. Tons of Accredo employee's talk down the the ESI employee's very sad. They promote we are one company know but how come Accredo IV specialist received bonus but ESI employee's got nothing. Accredo employee's are paid better than ESI employee's so stop lying to employee's by saying we are one company. Another thing ESI is good about laying employee's off around the holiday's everyday I worry I am not going to have a job. I have devoted myself to this company, gone home after working 10 to 12 hours days 7 days a week, have bent over backwards to get the job done and feel like I everyday I don't know if I will have a job. Be prepared employee's the holiday is coming and so are the pink slips. With what you pay your Accredo employee's let some of them go and the company will save some money. If I could find another job I would leave but I have not found one yet, as soon as I do I am gone.
Very sad, management does not read these and take notice of a declining situation.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Its a fast and rapid pace work environment - get it done is the norm here. Plenty of projects with lots of work and deadlines throughout the organization. Lots of smart people.
cons: Organization is not really employee focused and the culture treats employees as dispensable. The employee attrition and churn are extremely high and there is not long term focus on personal growth.

review_title: Overall a good company to work for, but work/life balance is a huge issue.
pros: Good pay and benefits. Ability to work from home is there for many, but not all departments. Great people in "the trenches" who are dedicated and want to "do the right thing."
cons: Poor work and home life balance. Expected to work most holidays. Often expected to work on paid vacation days off and not compensated for doing so; it is expected.

pros: Currently the leading PBM in the industry, innovative use of big data from processing Rx drug claims, interesting business.
cons: Poor opportunities for upward mobility; Notoriously cheap company; Benefits ok, but severely underpay salaries compared to other companies in industry; Not appreciative of "over and beyond" contributions of employees.  Poor employee morale due to poor job security.

review_title: Senior Patient Care Advocate-Inbound Call Team
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I used to enjoy my job until we merged with Medco and my department became a call team. My role is not defined as a customer service rep, but it feels like I am in some sense.
cons: The department that I work in feels as though it's slowly dwindling away even though upper management states that it's not. We have daily changes to our work processes and policies and procedures. Raises never seem like enough. Speaking to disgruntled patients and having limitations on what you can actually do to help

pros: Free coffee, water and ice.  I had a good team lead. I enjoyed my co-workers.  Overall enjoyed working there.
cons: "Adherence" to schedule was a little ridiculous at times. It was an icebox everyday! Help your members but get them off the phone as quickly as possible.  I think customer service was compromised because of that.

review_title: If you're looking for a career, this is the place for you!!!!
job_title: Team Lead in Saint Marys, GA
pros: I had never worked in a call center environment before stepping through the doors of this company, there I was...barely 21 years old, I've onyl had 6 months of experience on the phone and decided that i was going to apply for the TL position that just became available. There were several big time candidates for the position that had gone through their emerging leader role so I was fairly confident that I was not going to get the position, a week goes by and the managers call me into the site one morning to let me know that I got the position as TL!!!  This company knows what potential looks like and is willing to give everyone an opportunity to advance as long as your willing to step into the manager's office and get to know them on a day to day basis, I'm not a shy guy..I like to converse with my manager sand I told them everyday what i was goign to do with this company, with no college education...I was given a position to lead other advocates and use my experience to motivate these employees....I've never even kept a job for more than 6 months...Express Scripts is a blessing..not only have I become a team lead, I am now pushing my new advocates who have just hit the floor 2 weeks ago to become emerging leaders and get them opportunites as POC and helping in the new hire class. I went from an advocate barely making my P4P to a salary position almost overnight!!!!This really is a great career!!!!
cons: None, like I said..as long as you're willing to put the hard work in..you can find opportunites quick and you don't even need previous experience or even knowledge of the job, they will help you succeed by giving you training.....it's a great place to work..believe me!!!!

review_title: I have worked for the company for over 10 years and it.
job_title: Technical Writer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: One of the best things about woring there is the ability to work fro home.
cons: The company does not hire from within very often, and pay raises are not very good.

job_title: Project Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
The benefits are great and extensive. The salary ranges are very competitive and they are willing to negotiate with you to remain flexible within reasonable expectations.

The culture is innovative, forward-thinking, fast-paced (seriously...it is), and open-minded. All of my previous employers acted like they valued your opinion or suggestion to improve a process, but ESI really does take it into consideration all the way up the chain before a decision is made. You have a voice here, and that's really impressed me. A plus is that the whole entire campus is brand new (2007 and newer) and state-of-the-art.

Never a dull moment or shortage of work to do. On that note, outside people hear a lot about work-life imbalance at ESI, but I just don't see that. Every single person here pulls their own weight in the same direction working toward a common goal, and nobody gripes about it. You can see people genuinely care about their work, and it's shown objectively when just about everyone regularly hits 100% or more of their annual bonus plan. I don't know about you, but I'd rather HAVE work to do than sit at my desk all day and have nothing to do (been there before, it's miserable). A lot of the mixed reviews I see are from the frustration of the constant integrating and merging of newly acquired companies' employees and processes, which is understandable, but the focus is definitely changing to efficiency and making work/life easier. I believe if there is a work-life imbalance that it is silo'd into certain departments, but it's certainly not a company-wide issue.
cons: Not really any glaring Cons, I just think people need to socialize a little more. Everyone works hard and has the go-go-go mentality, but it wouldn't hurt to loosen up and have a little fun here and there.

review_title: A shell of what once was.
job_title: Business Analyst in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: The co-workers are one of the greatest assets aside from a 401k that matched up to 6%. Great cafe and nice campus in northern NJ.
cons: The yearly merit increases were between a dismal 1-2% per year. Their benefits have worsened (ironic given that they are a benefit management company).

job_title: Production Clerk in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I work in the pharmacy  department, manual labor and  long hours. The pay is decent, however, this is not a good position if you have other commitments. There's only two shifts twice a day and everyday except Saturday evening, which is used for  mandatory overtime when needed. All the good days are taken! The befits are good, but like I said this job is not for people with other commitments like family and/or other demanding activities.
cons: Long days long hours and no time for family or self

job_title: Account Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
I have held two different positions at Express Scripts, both of which have been challenging, but rewarding.   The general mission of express scripts is to improve the health outcomes of our patients by making medication accessible and affordable.    In both of my roles here, I have felt directly connected to that mission, and in many cases, that I specifically helped make a difference.  Working for ESI is a fast-paced environment - expectations are set high, and are rewarded when achieved.   This is definitely not a place to come work and slack off, as we handle sensitive situations involving healthcare and drugs.   

Express Scripts is committed to hard work that produces good results, integrity and diversity.  I have always felt that the door is open to senior management if I have a concern with a particular process or situation.   Our benefits packages are great, and as an openly gay employee (which the company is very cool with), they offer the full range of benefits to my partner as well.   

I strongly feel that the company offers room for growth and advancement, and for those employees that work hard and excel at what they do, management is apt to help them advance and become leaders.
cons: We do work hard, and long hours.   The company is committed to eliminating fraud, waste and abuse, which extends to it's own workforce.   Sometimes work environments can be stressful, as the problems we solve are complex and often require a quick solution.   My biggest con is that employee performance is rated on a bell curve, which sometimes pits team members to work in direct competition with each other to receive a good review.

review_title: Express Scripts Canada is difficultly trying to renovate itself

Company trying to renovate by leveraging new technologies but thinks this is possible without mastering the technology! Instead, it's trying to leverage local and international vendors but things are moving difficultly with lots of problems. The company is clearly not mastering its IT projects.
Requires lots of do-it-yourself.
Very little opportunity for learning, especially in IT.

I did the job of three people and never received as much as a thank you. ESI absolutely lives up to it's reputation. I wonder if any legacy Express Scripts employees were left go after the merger. review_title: AVOID THIS COMPANY OR YOU ARE DOOMED!!!
pros: LOL. Pros. Is that a joke?
cons: Everything except the pay. Nothing too special, but 12.75 to sit and take calls is not bad. But that's where the good starts and ends. Their policies are horrible. They will fire you at the drop of a dime, just because. My training class started with about 25 people and most of them either got fired or quit because it was just horrible. Google worst companies to work for... You'll see what I mean. Luckily, I had another job and was able to quit before they fired me too. Just don't work here...

review_title: The company deserves 1 star, but I still care. For now.
pros: Despite the staff loss and attrition post merger, there are still pockets of good people left in both legacy companies.
cons:
Leadership Problem

Desired company values set forth by management is in-congruent to actual work directives.   On one hand, management asks us to do what is best for our Members.  On the other hand, they ask us to do what is best for our Clients.  Then there's the need to generate revenue for the company.

If you know anything about insurance industry, this is fundamentally conflicting mandates that cannot be reconciled.  Between Clients, Members, and Express Scripts, only 2 out of 3 parties can be happy at any given point.

Despite the management mantra, our current business model disincentivizes us from doing what is best for our members and clients because disproportionate amount of the company profit is tied to script volume.  The more sick our members are, higher the script volume, and more money Express Scripts make. We are a one-trick pony.

Wall Street-consumption-ready sound bite about our diversified revenue streams is largely a farce. It doesn't matter if the revenue sources are evenly split between specialty drugs, mail order, service fees, and rebates if the size of the overall pie is completely dependent on the script volume.  This is not true diversification.

For true diversification and script-agnostic growth strategy, the company needs think outside the box it is trapped in, and invest in innovative strategies and people.  On the surface the company has been trying to be position itself as all-in-one, benefits management company, pharmacy, healthcare provider, and research institution.  But it is failing in all of them.

Take the Big Data opportunity as an example.  As a PBM, we are sitting on mountains of empirical data about members, providers, treatment, and outcome.  We are not using them to drive growth in meaningful ways, because we are willfully ignoring data points that can improve member outcome and lower costs, but that can potentially reduce script volume.

Instead, the big data is being used mostly for client marketing purpose (a.k.a Express Scripts Lab) and cut operating expenses, rather than meaningfully growing top-line.



Pay problem.

The current HR compensation structure and performance management system are designed to attract and retain mediocrity.  Many good people have already left and we are left with smart, but sour staff who've been chronically underpaid, and now even more sour than ever.

Paying market rate salary is not going to work with Express Scripts.  In order to attract and retain good talent, the company needs to be paying above market rate.  When you have a problem that can easily be solved by literally throwing more money at it, you say "thank you" and start throwing cash.

After the merger, management significantly reduced options and RSUs for middle managers and top talents to the point of insult.  Long term incentive is a key strategy in retaining top talents.



IT-pocalypse

The company suffers from weak IT leadership, particularly at Sr. Director level and above.  We are in a sore need to recruit highly competent, bold, leaders from a proven technology company to clean up the disastrous IT foundations that are root of cause of many project failures and hindrance to new initiatives.

The current leadership positions are all occupied by 50 something year old males or (30-40 year old females) with dubious technical skills who think going 'agile' is as easy as saying abracadabra and its utterance alone provides magical 30% productivity boost.

News Flash: Express Scripts is not set up for agile, and to its fairness, most large companies are not either.

What the company needs is a new IT visionary and his/her lieutenants that will stand up to the senior management and call spade a spade, but smart enough to recognize when the lower level staff is serving turd sandwiches with PB&J.



Organizational culture and structure problem.

There is culture of business-worship that results in gross mis-allocation of resources. There are literally hundreds of directors on the business side with no direct reports while other department directors have to manage staff of half a dozen to hundreds.  And the ugly truth is, we have some of the weakest and woefully under-qualified business and product owners I have seen in my career.

And in order to 'serve' business needs better, management inserted liaison roles between business and IT called them "BAT" or "BIAC"; roles that were traditionally performed by business analysts and project managers.  In theory, this specialization of roles sounds like a good idea from resource management perspective.  In practice, it results in IT project managers who are effectively clueless about the details of the projects they are managing, business analysts whose roles have been marginalized, and across the board staff bloat.

review_title: Major overhaul needed for morale issues.
pros: Large corporation with decent benefits and opportunities for furthering one's education

pros: I started in the Company when it was Medco Health Solutions and then sold to Express Scripts.  10+ year employee.  The original training was excellent.  Holiday/Vacation Pay/PTO/ Sometimes OT a plus.  When there was a building, you could make great friends with coworkers.  Good insurance and benefits package.
cons: After the buy out Las Vegas was the Step Child, even though we were the best trained team in the company. Pay/Insurance/Vacation/Time Bank/OT/Paid Holidays were great until the Buy Out.  After Buy Out  we still had these things but higher premiums, deductibles, etc., Vacation time was shortened and it wasn't separate from PTO.  We had to work 1600 hours in a year, previously, to get our next years vacation time, when we rolled into 2015, all we worked for was dropped so we rolled into 2015 with no Vacation/PTO and then it accrued weekly.  Pay was also reduced if you stayed with the company.  New hire  pay is about 12.50 p/h but very low annual raise %.  No real respect for employees or members.  Cut the call as short as possible. If you helped the member good but if not make them think you did and say it nice.  If a call took anytime to resolve (usually less trained PCS giving out wrong info or complicated Ins the members didn't understand contributed to this) you were given demerits, if you tried to resolve issues properly, if it took more than 5 minutes.  This caused you to loose your bonus.  The CEO (George Paz) was not a person who cared if there was quality attention to the members. Remember this is a Prescription Benefit Management Co, getting people their medicine.  I hope the new CEO has a different outlook.

review_title: This place is a hot mess.
pros: So far, my meager weekly check has never bounced and I did get and equally meager raise. I'll try not to spend it all at one place.

Middle and upper management is so far removed from the realities of the actual job and the staff that performs it.They foster a hostile work environment by blaming and shaming staff for issues completely out of their control. Supervisors aren't supposed to foster development and growth of their team members. Instead, they are to be MIA for 2/3 of their shift blowing smoke up each other's can while kissing up to our painfully inept management. Upward mobility is a myth. Moving to another department cannot happen. Transfers to other sites are also not allowed. Raises are insulting. Getting a good quality score is an absolute crap shoot. The metrics used to gage productivity is shoddy at best, it can be, and is, manipulated by staff to gain better pay raises (still never above 3% so I don't know why they bother.) Budgets are blown on stupid campaigns like "March Madness" and equally childish distractions (that $ could have been someone's raise!) Real issues are kept from people high enough to make changes (though it's obvious progress is of no concern of theirs or they would make themselves visible and available and know of all goings on.) Threats and intimidation are the default management style of middle management and their lacky supervisors. Certain people are not to be contacted EVER without prior approval from Sr. Management, lest you feel the wrath of a good tongue lashing for daring to bring legitimate concerns to VPs and HR. The list goes on and on.

review_title: I heard it could be better in headquarters...

cons: There is a lot of favoritism and they control who performs "stretch." Turnover is a must because of all the politics here. People get fired and do not know the full reason why. When I quit people joked about how I lasted the 2 weeks and they did not fire me before it was up.

pros: Growth means lots of projects.  The company takes on lots and as a result there is money and interesting work to do. Management values doers in the manner of smaller companies.

review_title: THE ABSOLUTE WORST COMPANY I HAVE EVER WORKED FOR
pros: The great people I had the pleasure of working with for many years
cons: I see a lot of comments about work/life balance, which is most likely people working in corporate.  Well here is how it is in the trenches.  This is the worst company I have ever worked for in my whole career.  After the merger, ESRX introduced us to their form of management.  It is modeled after the car company Toyota and called Kaizen.  This company thinks production is production whether you are resolving a DUR issue with maybe 15 different interactions and several different doctors, or screwing in lug nuts.  Every job has a SWI (SOP) about how to do each part of it and it is broken down to seconds.  You have so many seconds to do each task whether it be a simple edit to resolve or one with multiple issues that requires research.  Every time there is a new or updated SWI, it is sent to you via email, but you are not allowed to read it while you are in production.  Each job classification has a "Kaizen board" in their section with your employee number and the previous days' production.   You are either red, yellow or green  (threshold, target, stretch).  There are even red, yellow and green stoplights in each department-just like on the assembly line!  There are other items on the board about how to improve things, which boils down to how can we make you work faster.  The company is constantly raising the goal.  If you do not reach the goal, you are put in the disciplinary process!  They use some other euphemism, but it is disciplinary.  Every 2 weeks, you meet with your supervisor, and if you haven't improved your rate, you proceed to the next step of discipline up to and including dismissal.  Under- goal rates are considered bad behavior.  So to be a good employee, you have to work faster than what your normal comfort zone is.  This causes people to ignore things they would otherwise question which greatly increases your possibility of making a life threatening error.  This is no longer a Pharmacy-it has been transformed into a factory.  That is why this job is so stressful.  It's no wonder Toyota had to put fences around upper story windows to keep employees from jumping out of them.

job_title: IT Manager in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: You get out of the house and don't need to watch TV to pass the time. You might be able to pay some of your bills with the blood money they squeeze out of their clients
cons: Management has no clue it's 2013 not 1993. Management is more concerned with squeezing money from its clients than providing actual drug coverage. Consultants are treated better than employees and when you try to say, hey this guy doesn't know his stuff - you are attacked and complained about and the consultant continues to produce sub standard work (which btw is dangerous because they do distribute life saving drugs)

job_title: Senior Manager in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: Flexible work/life balance, that was really the only reason why I stayed so long here - the ability to work from home on snow days and if needed for medical appts or when my child was ill.
cons: Management is horrible.  No help when needed and felt there was no guidance when needed or no room for advancement at all.  There is also a lot of favoritism there, if your not a part of the "good crowd", your not going anywhere in this company.

review_title: Some good people, but this company does not care about employees
pros:
Location for me
Jeans to work every day
cons:
Salary is under the average
Upper management totally out of touch with employees
ZERO work/life balance - if you mention the term " work/life balance" to management they get very defensive
No growth opportunities in NJ

pros:
1. Work-From-Home access (by some managers)
2. Flexible hours. My manager allows us to work any time as long as we put in our eight hours every week. I usually do 7-3, because I'm an early bird, but we can do anything from 6-2 to 11-7.
cons:
1. I began during the slow months so my work-life balance hasn't taken a hit. However, it is an insurance company. So when 1/1/2015 comes, previous employees guarantee 2 hours of sleep per night. However, the environment is so stressful that it effects my personal life.
2. The company has no direction on large and small scales. Many employees don't even know what their roles are.
3. They hire several (10-100) employees at a time without preparing for them. It takes months to get a laptop and VPN access. New hires twiddle their thumbs for the first one to two months and watch Netflix all day. This might seem as a "pro" so some, but when applying to new jobs, there will be nothing write about on your resume.
4. Most employees are contractors so they have no room for growth. Those who are FT employees have no sense of direction. The training materials are very weak and only cover the tip of the iceberg. 
5. ESI pretends to care about their employees by posting documents and sending emails that serve to raise morale, but they do not. When they purchased Medco about two years ago, they fired thousands of employees and then re-hired for the same positions as contractors to save money. No morals whatsoever.
6. Senior management has their head in the clouds. They cannot provide direction nor do they understand proper business communications. They pay no attention to the employees and management under them.
7. Not a trace of organization. Everything is ad-hoc. Employees are volunteered by management to execute new tasks without proper training materials.
8. Management has absolutely no idea what the responsibilities of the employees under them are. This paired with their pathetic communication skills leads to unrealistic expectations for both parties.

pros: Pay is good, great team of coworkers, flexible schedule, longevity employees accumulate 2 days a pay period of PTO. Job itself is not hard.
cons: Employees are overworked. Planning for high volume seasons/quarters is not done adequately which causes the employees to work a lot of "required" OT. It's not staffed to handle the influx of volume that come ls throughout the year.

pros: best reasons to work there - other than the friendships you develop, there really were not any!
cons: Senior Management is completely out of touch; many have Engineering background  and cannot relate at all to pharmacy.  Employee managers are a joke, most uneducated and unprofessional, and they expect employees to respect them.  Treat employees like dogs, no talking, no socializing without being written up.  Employee managers play favorites.

job_title: Senior Account Executive in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Awesome benefits that's are always evolving and getting better. A focus on internal career advancement through mentoring, coaching and hands on learning opportunities. Strong recognition programs for high performers.
cons: Some departments do have strict  guidelines on required OT and working on weekends as needed.

pros: The people are outstanding, great folks to grow among all focused on driving the success of ESI - across all locations.
cons: Infighting and downright lying over system capabilities in hopes that the platform you're advocating for will be the chosen path ahead, so that you and all your pals won't be laid off.  Instead watch the folks who built the company be let go due to the untruths.

cons: While I was there, ESI was extremely lean and middle management lacked the ability to be a champion of their respective teams.  Also, middle management seemed to lack the ability to think strategically and just managed employees instead of being real leaders.  Positions seemed undergraded but since I have left I heard positions have been regraded and there have been salary adjustments.

review_title: Low-tier Company for Mediocre Talent in a Toxic Environment
job_title: Senior Manager  in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
I experienced a great deal of autonomy, but I can't say if that's usual or not (see my comments in the next section).  I think that, in general, if you keep your head down and do just what you're told without asking too many questions, you'll probably be OK.  Some people are fine with being a 'cog in the wheel'; if that's what you're looking for, this might be a place to consider.  ESI still has a reputation in the general community as a good place to work, so it could be advantageous to have it on your resume if you're building a career in pharma and related businesses.

The lunch facilities are very good and reasonably priced; about half the people bring their lunch, and half take advantage of the Aramark-operated fresh lunch option.  There is a variety of freshly-prepared options, including numerous healthy choices.  There is also a coffee/ smoothie bar with snacks open for a few hours when the lunch room is not.  Parking is adequate, and more covered parking is being added.

ESI has some relationship with University of Missouri, St. Louis (on whose campus the HQ resides), and there may be opportunity for educational benefits as a result.

Benefits are basic; some companies have better, but some certainly have worse.

People mostly keep to themselves.
cons:
If you are top-tier talent, this will not be a good place to grow your career.  ESI will teach bad habits, and will not support good ones.  You will not be able to influence change for the better.  You will receive no training, no education about the industry, and none about the overall function of the company and its goals.  You will be asked to put on blinders, to do a narrowly defined tightly prescribed task, and not ask questions, not try to learn.  Express Scripts is not a company guided by principles and vision.  People speak with cynical pride about some of the things they've done to save money that are ultimately at the expense of patients.

When I knew that ESI would not be a long-term situation for me, I asked a few select people about some of my observations of being a terribly silo-ed workplace with no communication and no leadership; they laughed and said, "Yeah, that's the way it is here.  It's been that way for as long as I can remember [around 20 years]."

ESI pays below industry standard, and does not retain top talent.  People who have been with the company for a long time are those who have learned to keep their heads down and mouths shut.  They typically have little other work experience to compare to the ESI culture.

I experienced a reasonable amount of autonomy in my job, but I think in retrospect that that was because there was such poor management.  No one ever seems happy to be there; no one makes eye contact; no one says 'Good morning" or in any way expresses any pleasure at working at this company.  There is a daily pervasive sense of frustration or dread, and a culture of 'staying below the radar screen'.

There is little if any coordination between departments or work teams.  Theoretically, everyone should be working toward the same company goal, but the lack of communication and the presence of territoriality -hostility and protectionism- leads to duplication and wasted time and resources, and to an environment of low morale and job dissatisfaction.

Work areas are labeled with signs hanging from the ceiling, but work teams are very frequently spread out randomly across the facility, rather than with desks and workspaces in close proximity which would allow and encourage collaboration.  Space is at a premium, but no one seems concerned about organizing it.

Nepostism and cronyism is the standard for making hiring and promotion decisions.  ESI, just like every other company these days, claims to be a "high performance company" or "driven by performance".  The nearly complete absence of training, the amateurish new employee orientation, and the systemic inefficiencies refute this claim for Express Scripts.  Promotions have little if anything to do with qualifications; they have more to do with cronyism.  Very often, management hired from outside the company are castoffs, hired on the cheap, not for proven ability or performance.  There are also numerous examples of hiring people for high-level positions of responsibility  -with other people's livelihoods in their hands-  who have no experience and minimal ability to learn or learn quickly.  So, then everyone else is more pressured to 'perform', but dragged down because it was more important to hire the incompetent relative of some other manager or executive.

Senior level executives seem unaware of this and other practices, or unmotivated to recognize the problems caused to overall performance of the company.  If shareholders knew, one wonders how they'd respond to such waste and inefficiency.  It is essentially stealing, to hire incompetent people for unethical reasons, and bring down performance as a result, while expending resources (including salaries and benefits) on people who should not be in their positions.

People seem to be with ESI either for a long time or a very short time.  Those who've been there for a long time have very little if any experience elsewhere, so they have little to compare their ESI work experience to; they don't know how bad ESI is as a company and as an employer.  Those who are there for a short time usually leave because they know better, or because their resistance to the standard operating procedures can't be accomodated by supervisors who are consistently in over their heads when it comes to their responsibilities to provide leadership; these 'leaders' are threatened by subordinate competence and persistantely afraid for their jobs, and overwhelmed with workload.  There is no work/life balance, the higher up the chain you go.  'Leaders' do not know how to delegate, much less lead people.

Also, the facilities  -the shiny new St. Louis HQ- should be an embarrassment to a company that wishes to compete on this level of revenue and market competition.  Everything from lighting, floor coverings, heating and air conditioning, computers and IT, is just basic, used and well-worn.  This might be acceptable for a non-profit with a small budget, but for a company which needs to foster innovation and develop competitive strategies and actions, it merely adds another disspiriting layer to the management style of incompetence, oppression and back-biting.
